TravelBuddy.description: Your personal AI travel planner. A React Native app that takes care of your travel plans.
content: Travel Buddy is an Android app that helps you plan your trips. It uses AI to suggest destinations, activities, and accommodations based on your preferences, budget, and travel dates.

The app is built using React Native, MongoDB, Firebase and Google Cloud Vertex AI. It features a user-friendly interface that allows you to easily input your travel details and receive personalized recommendations.
A history of your past trips is stored in the app, so you can easily refer back to them when planning future trips. Favorite trips can be saved for quick access.

I worked on this project as part of a team of four developers. My role was to design and implement the backend and integrate the AI features. I also contributed to the frontend development and testing.

LinuxWebservices.description: Automated Kubernetes setup, deployment, and monitoring with Vagrant and Prometheus.
content: This project is an automated setup for deploying and monitoring web services using Kubernetes, Docker, Vagrant, and Prometheus. It provides a complete solution for setting up a scalable and reliable web service infrastructure.

The project includes a Vagrantfile that sets up a Kubernetes cluster with multiple nodes. It also includes Dockerfiles for building the web service containers and Kubernetes configuration files for deploying the services.
Prometheus is used for monitoring the health and performance of the web services. It collects metrics from the services and provides a dashboard for visualizing the data in Graphana.

I developed this project as part of a course on Linux web services. It was a great learning experience that helped me gain a deeper understanding of containerization, orchestration, and monitoring tools.

WTC.description: A website for the WTC-Roland cycling club, to manage events and memberships.
content: The WTC-Roland Club website is a Laravel-based web application that provides a platform for managing club events and memberships. It features a user-friendly interface that allows club management to create and manage events, track memberships, and communicate with members through emails.

The website is built using Laravel, Livewire, Tailwind CSS, and Alpine.js. It includes a custom admin panel for managing events, memberships, and user accounts. The admin panel provides tools for creating new events, sending notifications to members, and editing email templates.

I developed this project as part of a team school project. My role was to design and implement parts of the backend functionality, mainly the email system. I also contributed to the frontend design and development.

The website has been well received by the teachers at our school. It has been a great learning experience that has helped me improve my skills in web development and dealing with real-world requirements.

CTK.description: Onepager for a charity event to raise funds for cancer research. A volunteer project.
content: Volunteering for 'Comedy Tegen Kanker', a charity event supporting cancer research, I was tasked with creating their online presence. The goal was to build a single-page website providing event details, performer information, and links for ticket sales.

I utilized HTML, CSS, JavaScript, and Bootstrap to develop a responsive website that adapts to different screen sizes. This ensured accessibility for all potential attendees and donors, regardless of their device.
Launching the website provided a platform to promote the event and facilitate fundraising, making my contribution a rewarding experience in supporting a significant cause.

Proxmox.description: A personal homelab setup for self-hosting services and learning new technologies.
content: In my free time, I enjoy setting up and maintaining a personal homelab for self-hosting services and experimenting with new technologies. My homelab runs on Proxmox, a virtualization platform that allows me to create and manage virtual machines and containers.

I use Docker and Kubernetes to deploy and manage the services in my homelab. Some of the services I host include this website, an OpenWebUI instance for running AI chatbots, a Jellyfin media server, and a Pi-hole ad blocker.
I also have a few Raspberry Pi's that I use for testing and learning purposes. It's a fun and educational way to explore different technologies and build new projects.

My homelab has been a valuable resource for learning and experimenting with new technologies. It has helped me gain hands-on experience with virtualization, containerization, networking and cyber security.

UC.description: Modeling and analysis of requirements for a software project using UML diagrams.
content: This project involved modeling and analyzing the requirements for a software project using UML diagrams. The project was part of a course on software modelling and requirements analysis.

The project included creating use case diagrams and class diagrams to model the requirements of the software project. The diagrams were used to document the functional and non-functional requirements of the system.
Wireframes were created to visualize the user interface of the software. The wireframes were used to gather feedback from stakeholders and refine the design of the system.

Trello was used to manage the project requirements and track the progress of the project. The project was part of the WTC-Roland Club website project, which aimed to create a platform for managing club events and memberships.

The project helped me gain a deeper understanding of analyzing and modeling requirements based on client needs. It was a valuable learning experience that has helped me improve my skills in software design and requirements analysis.
